importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article covers the recent event of Sanae Takaichi being elected Japan's first female prime minister in 2025, marking a historic moment in Japanese political history.

keyTakeAways: Sanae Takaichi is Japan's first female prime minister, breaking a long-standing gender barrier in a country where women held only about 10% of parliamentary seats as of 2024.
Takaichi is an ultraconservative leader with traditional views on gender roles, including opposition to same-sex marriage and male-only succession to the Japanese throne.
She has a strong hawkish stance on China, advocating for stricter immigration controls, anti-espionage laws, and restrictions on foreign property ownership in Japan.
Takaichi has drawn comparisons to Margaret Thatcher, emphasizing her strength and traditional conservatism, while also expressing admiration for her and wearing blue suits in tribute.
Despite being the first female leader, she has not prioritized gender equality, appointing only two women to her cabinet, falling short of her promise to reach Nordic-level representation (50%).

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sanae Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister, is an ultraconservative figure with traditional views on gender and history, having been elected after forming an alliance with a right-wing populist party. A long-time LDP member and former minister of international communications under Shinzo Abe, she has drawn comparisons to Margaret Thatcher, expressing admiration for her strength and conservative ideology. Takaichi is controversial for her opposition to same-sex marriage, her criticism of post-WWII war crime trials, her visits to the Yasukuni Shrine, and her hardline anti-immigration policies. Despite promising to increase women in her cabinet to Nordic levels, she appointed only two women. She also appears friendly toward U.S. President Donald Trump, who praised her, and is expected to meet with him during a visit to Japan. Her rise marks a historic shift in Japanese politics, yet her policies and views raise concerns about gender equality and historical revisionism.
title: 5 things to know about Sanae Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister
